title: 113_s2417
content: The "Close the Revolving Door Act of 2014" is a bill that includes a lifetime ban on members of Congress from lobbying. The bill "Close the Revolving Door Act of 2014" amends Section 207(e)(1) of title 18, United States Code, to impose penalties on former Senators, Members of the House of Representatives, or elected officers who attempt to influence current members of Congress on behalf of others. Additionally, Section 207(e)(2) is amended to remove the reference to elected officers of the Senate. SEC. 3. CONGRESSIONAL STAFF amended to increase the restriction period to 6 years. SEC. 4. Improved reporting of lobbyists' activities through a joint web database called lobbyists.gov. SEC. 5. Addresses the issue of the lobbyist revolving door to Congress. Any person who is a registered lobbyist or agent of a foreign principal cannot be hired by a Member or committee of Congress within 6 years of leaving their position. A waiver can be granted by the Committee on Ethics or the Committee on Standards of Official Conduct in cases of compelling national need. The determination of substantial lobbying contact includes considering if the lobbying pertained to legislative business, earmarks, federal funding, coordination of meetings, presentations to staff, or fundraising beyond personal contributions. The definition of substantial lobbying contact includes lobbying related to legislative business, earmarks, federal funding, coordination of meetings, presentations to staff, or fundraising beyond personal contributions. Simple social contacts with Members or staff of Congress do not count as substantial lobbying contacts. SEC. 6A. REPORTING BY SUBSTANTIAL LOBBYING ENTITIES. The Lobbying Disclosure Act of 1995 is amended to include reporting requirements for substantial lobbying entities. A substantial lobbying entity must annually file a list of former members of Congress or congressional staff who meet specific criteria with the Clerk of the House of Representatives and the Secretary of the Senate. The filing should include a brief job description of each individual. The filing required by this section must contain a brief job description of employees, individuals under contract, or consultants, along with their work experience. The Joint Web site lobbyists.gov will have a database for 'Substantial Lobbying Entities' for easy search. The Clerk of the House and the Secretary of the Senate will provide filings to the District of Columbia US Attorney for oversight on underreporting lobbying activities. The section requires disclosure of Federal lobbying activities by employees, contractors, and consultants of substantial lobbying entities employing more than 3 federally registered lobbyists. SEC. 7 of the Lobbying Disclosure Act of 1995 is amended to increase penalties from $200,000 to $500,000.
